description: This collection uses primary sources to explore the golden age of musical theatre on Broadway.

isRelatedTo.name: A 1943 Theatre Guild press release for *Away We Go!*, the pre-Broadway title of *Oklahoma!*.
A photograph of Richard Rodgers conducting the 2,000th performance of *Oklahoma!* on Broadway.
A photograph of a scene from the revival production of *On the Town* in 1971.

A photograph of Eliza, the main character from *My Fair Lady*, in a late 1950s performance.
A news story about a 2014 revival of *My Fair Lady* and a recording of the song “I Think She’s Got it!”.
The cover of the *Playbill* from the original Broadway production of *West Side Story* in 1957.
A photograph of the characters Harold Hill and Marian the Librarian from *The Music Man*.
A photograph of the original Broadway cast in a 1959 performance of *The Sound of Music*.

affiliation.name: Lexington School District One, South Carolina

hasPart.name: Questions
hasPart.text:
1. In what ways are the societal roles of women reflected throughout this set? Cite specific textual evidence from at least three different sources that support your claim.
2. Compare the “About Tonight’s Play” excerpts. What parallels do you see in the storylines and role of women in *Kiss Me Kate* and *Gypsy*?
3. Look at the photograph and recording of *My Fair Lady*, a “rags to riches” story that has been revived several times on Broadway. Why do you think this is the case? What is it about this story that continues to captivate audiences even today?
4. Describe the value of a revival. In looking at the photographs and items specifically from revival performances, identify what seems to make a show worthy of reviving. Do you think that social conditions in the 1970s, for instance, mirrored those of the 1940s and 50s?

hasPart.name: Activity
hasPart.text:
Ask students to research modern musicals and revivals to determine what aspects of “golden age” musical are echoed in more recent shows. Each student should choose a recent show: *Cats*, *Wicked*, *Phantom of the Opera*, *Les Miserables*, or another musical. Each student should create a flowchart that shows how musicals of the 1940s and 1950s influenced the more recent musical they have chosen. Use the following sources as a springboard for this activity:

*[Theatre Development Foundation – Education Resources](https://www.tdf.org/nyc/35/EducationOverview)

*[Internet Broadway Database](http://www.ibdb.com/)

*[NYU Libguide on Theatre and Drama Databases](http://guides.nyu.edu/c.php?g=276890&p=1846405)

hasPart.name: Teaching Guide: Exploring the Golden Age of Broadway
Resources
hasPart.text:
1. [Internet Broadway Database](http://www.ibdb.com/), The Broadway League. 
2. [1943-1959: Golden Age](http://www.pbs.org/wnet/broadway/timelines/1943-1959) timeline, PBS. 
3. [History of the Theater District](http://www.spotlightonbroadway.com/broadway-history), Spotlight on Broadway.

hasPart.name: Overview
hasPart.text: Tucked into the enormous metropolis of Manhattan is a street with approximately forty theaters that contain 500 or more seats: Broadway. A name synonymous with “theater,” Broadway has always been a place where societal norms and boundaries are reflected and, in many cases, pushed to their limits. The “golden age” of Broadway was no exception. The period of the 1940s and 1950s was a tumultuous period in American history: The role of women was shifting, people were becoming more open to new styles of music, dance, art, and architecture, and World War II affected virtually every aspect of American culture. On Broadway things were changing as well. A new form of theater, the musical, was emerging as a force to be reckoned with under Rodgers and Hammerstein and other trailblazers in this new form. Whether sharing a memorable moment through a ballad or offering a comical interlude to lighten a serious topic, the musical was reshaping the way Americans saw theater and, in turn, themselves. As Americans witnessed the issues of their time on stage, they were able to see firsthand how times were changing throughout this “golden age” of Broadway.

isRelatedTo.name: Pop Art in the US
Rock 'n' Roll: Beginnings to Woodstock

name: The Golden Age of Broadway
